anns.postfix: (compound 3) was used as the substrate in the presence of NADPH, distinct product pairs were detected under aerobic versus anaerobic conditions (compounds 10 and 11 versus 14 and 17, respectively) (Fig. 4).

anns.postfix: 10 with a secondary alcohol at C-5, followed by a further reduction to afford the 5,6-diol 11 (Fig. 4a and b).

anns.prefix: Under anaerobic conditions,
anns.postfix: (compound 3) was converted by MrPigH into the tetrahydroxynaphthalene 14 by reductive aromatization, and further reduced and dearomatized to form the tetrahydroxytetralin 17 (Fig. 4a and c).

anns.postfix: (Fig. 4a and c).

anns.postfix: in the presence of oxygen (Fig. S4 [19]).

anns.prefix: The MABGC has previously been considered to have evolved to produce azaphilone pigments (MonAzPs) and to yield metabolites such as trihydroxynaphthalene 2 and
anns.postfix: (compound 3) only as shunt products upon the blockade of the normal course of MonAzP assembly (15, 16).

anns.prefix: However, we believe that this view of
anns.postfix: as mere derailment products is unjustified.

anns.prefix: First,
anns.postfix: production is elicited upon challenge by various microorganisms (Table S3 [19]), and these compounds show antifungal and antibacterial activities (Table S5 [19]).

anns.prefix: Second, the
anns.postfix: subcluster encodes not only biosynthetic enzymes but also a transcriptional regulator and proteins responsible for two distinct monasone resistance mechanisms (Fig. 2).

anns.prefix: In fact, several genes in MABGCs were found not to play an essential role in
anns.postfix: biosynthesis (15, 16).

anns.prefix: Thus, MonAzP biosynthesis sequesters the pluripotent and unstable polyketide intermediate 1 to afford
anns.postfix: , metabolites that occupy a distinct segment of the SM structural space compared to that by the ancestral naphthoquinones.

Just as with the
anns.postfix: biosynthetic gene supercluster, certain genes of these superclusters are involved in the biosynthesis of more than one SM, while other genes only take part in the biogenesis of one particular SM (28, 30).

anns.prefix: This mosaic nature of superclusters makes bioinformatic prediction of gene functions problematic, but coupled with functional analysis, it will help to illuminate the evolutionary paths that fungal
anns.postfix: biosynthesis has traveled.

anns.prefix: Our reassessment of
anns.postfix: as genuine SMs with ecological roles independent of those of MonAzPs was prompted by the observation that cocultivation of M. ruber M7 with other microorganisms stimulates the production of these naphthoquinones but not that of the azaphilones (Tables S3 and S4 [19]).

anns.prefix: Together with their antibacterial and antifungal activities, these results suggest that the biosynthesis of
anns.postfix: is an ecological fitness trait that helps M. ruber M7 defend its niche (32).

anns.prefix: At the same time, production of
anns.postfix: may be further promoted by optimizing cocultivation parameters by varying the microbial challengers and the interaction modes.

anns.prefix: Our results show that the
anns.postfix: producer M. ruber M7 may apply two-tiered self-defense by using the naphthoquinone-specific and naphthoquinone-inducible transporter MrPigP to expel monasones A and B from the mycelia and may utilize MrPigH and MrPigC to reduce residual intracellular monasones to compounds 12 and 16 that show no notable antimicrobial activity (Fig. 5).

anns.prefix: Unexpectedly, as shown by the ΔmrpigB strain,
anns.postfix: controls the expression of only six genes in the MABGC: mrpigA, the nrPKS; mrpigH, an enoyl reductase; mrpigM and mrpigO, an acetyltransferase-deacetylase pair; mrpigN, a flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)-dependent monooxygenase; and mrpigP, a major facilitator superfamily (MFS) transporter (Fig. 2b) (15).

anns.prefix: Furthermore, cocultivation did not restore the expression of these six genes in the ΔmrpigB strain, indicating that transcriptional activation of these genes upon elicitation is achieved primarily through MrPigB. anns.postfix: plays only a supplementary role in the biosynthesis of these pigments (15–17).

anns.prefix: The genes for
anns.postfix: naphthoquinone (monasone) biosynthesis are embedded in and form a composite supercluster with the Monascus azaphilone pigment biosynthetic gene cluster.

anns.prefix: Here, we report that the genes responsible for the biosynthesis of
anns.postfix: naphthoquinones (monasones) reside within the gene cluster for Monascus azaphilone pigments (MonAzPs).

anns.prefix: Recently, we found that 1,4-naphthoquinone-based natural product congeners with antimicrobial activities cooccur with
anns.postfix: azaphilone pigments (MonAzPs).

anns.prefix: The 1,4-naphthoquinone coproducts, hereinafter called monasones (
anns.postfix: naphthoquinones), are detectable only in trace amounts in MonAzP fermentations of wild-type isolates of Monascus spp.

anns.prefix: Our results show that the monasone producer
anns.postfix: may apply two-tiered self-defense by using the naphthoquinone-specific and naphthoquinone-inducible transporter MrPigP to expel monasones A and B from the mycelia and may utilize MrPigH and MrPigC to reduce residual intracellular monasones to compounds 12 and 16 that show no notable antimicrobial activity (Fig. 5).
